heading: net ipos line up to cash in
subheading: open the floodgates. the internet ipos are returning. the turn of seasons brings an onslaught of dot com companies jockeying to strike it rich. by joanna glasner.
author: joanna glasner
text: a slew of net companies are planning initial public offerings next week, wagering that investor demand will stay strong in the face of heightened competition. after several slow-paced weeks on the ipo market, the pace will accelerate dramatically next week. the pickings include a number of closely watched issues as well as some smaller deals.read more in ipo outlook- - - - - -unless sudden fear strikes wall street, analysts expect the bulk of them will do fine."as long as the tape remains as it is, quality deals will get done," said vincent slavin, an institutional trader with cantor fitzgerald.whether things will stay that way, however, is another question."i sense that we could see a little pullback, and things could get funky going into october," slavin said.analysts are paying close attention to a number of software issues, including e.piphany, a company that makes software for analyzing customer behavior at e-commerce sites, kana communications, which sells programs for managing customer email, and broadbase software, which specializes in e-commerce applications. netzero, one of several companies that offers free email and internet access in exchange for information about users, could be the largest ipo of the week. the company hopes to raise $100 million through its offering, which is being underwritten by goldman sachs.another closely watched new issue is alteon web systems, which makes products for speeding up data transmissions over telecommunications networks.others ipos likely to launch next week include luxury goods retailer ashford.com, and online sweepstakes operator webstakes cybergold, which runs a sort of "frequent clicker" program that rewards customers for clicking on designated sites.
